channel.title: IT-Security & Privacy News Aggregator
channel.description: Aggregierter RSS-Feed aus führenden IT-Security, Privacy und Cyber Policy Quellen

item.title: Iran-Linked RedKitten Cyber Campaign Targets Human Rights NGOs and Activists
item.description: A Farsi-speaking threat actor aligned with Iranian state interests is suspected to be behind a new campaign targeting non-governmental organizations and individuals involved in documenting recent human rights abuses. The activity, observed by HarfangLab in January 2026, has been codenamed RedKitten. It's said to coincide with the nationwide unrest in Iran that began towards the end of 2025,
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Mandiant Finds ShinyHunters-Style Vishing Attacks Stealing MFA to Breach SaaS Platforms
item.description: Google-owned Mandiant on Friday said it identified an "expansion in threat activity" that uses tradecraft consistent with extortion-themed attacks orchestrated by a financially motivated hacking group known as ShinyHunters. The attacks leverage advanced voice phishing (aka vishing) and bogus credential harvesting sites mimicking targeted companies to gain unauthorized access to victim
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CERT Polska Details Coordinated Cyber Attacks on 30+ Wind and Solar Farms
item.description: CERT Polska, the Polish computer emergency response team, revealed that coordinated cyber attacks targeted more than 30 wind and photovoltaic farms, a private company from the manufacturing sector, and a large combined heat and power plant (CHP) supplying heat to almost half a million customers in the country. The incident took place on December 29, 2025. The agency has attributed the attacks to
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Torq Moves SOCs Beyond SOAR With AI-Powered Hyper Automation
item.description: Investors poured $140 million into Torq's Series D Round, bringing the startup's valuation to $1.2 billion, to bring AI-based &quot;hyper automation&quot; to SOCs.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Schwartz

item.title: Friday Squid Blogging: New Squid Species Discovered
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: 2026: The Year Agentic AI Becomes the Attack-Surface Poster Child
item.description: Dark Reading asked readers whether agentic AI attacks, advanced deepfake threats, board recognition of cyber as a top priority, or password-less technology adoption would be most likely to become a trending reality for 2026.
item.dc:creator: Tara Seals

item.title: Out-of-the-Box Expectations for 2026 Reveal a Grab-Bag of Risk
item.description: Security teams need to be thinking about this list of emerging cybersecurity realities, to avoid rolling the dice on enterprise security risks (and opportunities).
item.dc:creator: Tara Seals

item.title: Tenable Tackles AI Governance, Shadow AI Risks, Data Exposure
item.description: The Tenable One AI Exposure add-on discovers unsanctioned AI use in the organization and enforces policy compliance with approved tools.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Schwartz

item.title: OpenClaw AI Runs Wild in Business Environments
item.description: The popular open source AI assistant (aka ClawdBot, MoltBot) has taken off, raising security concerns over its privileged, autonomous control within users' computers.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: SoundCloud Data Breach Exposes Nearly 30M User Accounts
item.description: <p>A SoundCloud breach affecting 29.8 million accounts exposed email addresses and profile data, increasing phishing risks.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-soundcloud-breach-exposes-nearly-30-million-users/">SoundCloud Data Breach Exposes Nearly 30M User Accounts</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Kezia Jungco

item.title: Apple Adds New iPhone Privacy Setting to Blur Location Data Shared With Carriers
item.description: <p>Apple’s new iPhone privacy setting blurs location data shared with wireless carriers, limiting precise tracking while preserving emergency services.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-apple-iphone-limit-precise-location-carriers/">Apple Adds New iPhone Privacy Setting to Blur Location Data Shared With Carriers</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Aminu Abdullahi

item.title: Labyrinth Chollima Evolves into Three North Korean Hacking Groups
item.description: CrowdStrike assessed that two new threat actor groups have spun off from North Korean Labyrinth Chollima hackers

item.title: AIs Are Getting Better at Finding and Exploiting Security Vulnerabilities
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: This month in security with Tony Anscombe – January 2026 edition
item.description: The trends that emerged in January offer useful clues about the risks and priorities that security teams are likely to contend with throughout the year

item.title: Researchers Uncover Chrome Extensions Abusing Affiliate Links and Stealing ChatGPT Access
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered malicious Google Chrome extensions that come with capabilities to hijack affiliate links, steal data, and collect OpenAI ChatGPT authentication tokens. One of the extensions in question is Amazon Ads Blocker (ID: pnpchphmplpdimbllknjoiopmfphellj), which claims to be a tool to browse Amazon without any sponsored content. It was uploaded to the Chrome
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: China-Linked UAT-8099 Targets IIS Servers in Asia with BadIIS SEO Malware
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a new campaign attributed to a China-linked threat actor known as UAT-8099 that took place between late 2025 and early 2026. The activity, discovered by Cisco Talos, has targeted vulnerable Internet Information Services (IIS) servers located across Asia, but with a specific focus on targets in Thailand and Vietnam. The scale of the campaign is currently
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: New AI-Developed Malware Campaign Targets Iranian Protests
item.description: The RedKitten campaign distributes lures designed to target people seeking information about missing persons or political dissidents in Iran

item.title: Badges, Bytes and Blackmail
item.description:
Behind the scenes of law enforcement in cyber: what do we know about caught cybercriminals? What brought them in, where do they come from and what was their function in the crimescape?
Introduction: One view on the scattered fight against cybercrime The growing sophistication and diversification of cybercrime have compelled law enforcement agencies worldwide to respond through increasingly
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: National Crime Agency and NatWest Issue Joint Warning Over Invoice Fraud Threat
item.description: Cyber fraudsters targeting corporate finance departments costs businesses millions a year

item.title: DynoWiper update: Technical analysis and attribution
item.description: ESET researchers present technical details on a recent data destruction incident affecting a company in Poland’s energy sector

item.title: Comcast to Pay $117M in Security Breach Settlement
item.description: <p>The breach was linked to a vulnerability known as “CitrixBleed,” a flaw affecting Citrix NetScaler Application Delivery Controller and Gateway appliances.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-comcast-security-breach-settlement/">Comcast to Pay $117M in Security Breach Settlement</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Ex-Google Engineer Convicted for Stealing AI Secrets for China Startup
item.description: A former Google engineer accused of stealing thousands of the company's confidential documents to build a startup in China has been convicted in the U.S., the Department of Justice (DoJ) announced Thursday. Linwei Ding (aka Leon Ding), 38, was convicted by a federal jury on seven counts of economic espionage and seven counts of theft of trade secrets for taking over 2,000 documents containing
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: SmarterMail Fixes Critical Unauthenticated RCE Flaw with CVSS 9.3 Score
item.description: SmarterTools has addressed two more security flaws in SmarterMail email software, including one critical security flaw that could result in arbitrary code execution. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-24423, carries a CVSS score of 9.3 out of 10.0. "SmarterTools SmarterMail versions prior to build 9511 contain an unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability in the ConnectToHub API
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Two Ivanti EPMM Zero-Day RCE Flaws Actively Exploited, Security Updates Released
item.description:
Ivanti has rolled out security updates to address two security flaws impacting Ivanti Endpoint Manager Mobile (EPMM) that have been exploited in zero-day attacks, one of which has been added by the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. The critical-severity vulnerabilities are listed below -
CVE-2026-1281 (CVSS score:
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Chinese APTs Hacking Asian Orgs With High-End Malware
item.description: Advanced persistent threat (APT) groups have deployed new cyber weapons against a variety of targets, highlighting the increasing threats to the region.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Trump Administration Rescinds Biden-Era Software Guidance
item.description: Federal agencies will no longer be required to solicit software attestations that they comply with NIST's Secure Software Development Framework (SSDF). What that means long term is unclear.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Second Round of Critical RCE Bugs in n8n Spikes Corporate Risk
item.description: A new around of vulnerabilities in the popular AI automation platform could let attackers hijack servers and steal credentials, allowing full takeover.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Researchers Find 175,000 Publicly Exposed Ollama AI Servers Across 130 Countries
item.description: A new joint investigation by SentinelOne SentinelLABS, and Censys has revealed that the open-source artificial intelligence (AI) deployment has created a vast "unmanaged, publicly accessible layer of AI compute infrastructure" that spans 175,000 unique Ollama hosts across 130 countries. These systems, which span both cloud and residential networks across the world, operate outside the
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Google Disrupts Extensive Residential Proxy Networks
item.description: Google has taken coordinated action against the massive IPIDEA residential proxy network, enhancing customer protections and disrupting cybercrime operations

item.title: Operation Winter SHIELD: FBI Issues Call to Arms for Organizations to Improve Cybersecurity
item.description: The FBI outlines ten actions which organizations can take to defend networks against cybercriminal and nation-state threats

item.title: France Fines National Employment Agency €5m Over 2024 Data Breach
item.description: The French data protection regulator said that France Travail’s response to a 2024 data breach violated GDPR

item.title: PCI Security Standards Council Publishes First-Ever Annual Report
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: 'Semantic Chaining' Jailbreak Dupes Gemini Nano Banana, Grok 4
item.description: If an attacker splits a malicious prompt into discrete chunks, some large language models (LLMs) will get lost in the details and miss the true intent.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: New CISA Guidance Targets Insider Threat Risks
item.description: CISA urges action against insider threats with publication of a new infographic offering strategies to manage risks

item.title: From Quantum to AI Risks: Preparing for Cybersecurity's Future
item.description: In the latest edition of &quot;Reporters' Notebook,&quot; a trio of journalists urge the cybersecurity industry to prioritize patching vulnerabilities, preparing for quantum threats, and refining AI applications,
item.dc:creator: Kristina Beek, Alexander Culafi

item.title: FBI Takes Down RAMP Ransomware Forum
item.description: The dark web forum administrator confirmed the takedown and said they had “no plans to rebuild”

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: New RCEs, Darknet Busts, Kernel Bugs & 25+ More Stories
item.description: This week’s updates show how small changes can create real problems. Not loud incidents, but quiet shifts that are easy to miss until they add up. The kind that affects systems people rely on every day. Many of the stories point to the same trend: familiar tools being used in unexpected ways. Security controls are being worked on. Trusted platforms turning into weak spots. What looks routine on
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Ransomware Victim Numbers Rise, Despite Drop in Active Extortion Groups
item.description: Ransomware victims surged in Q4 2025 despite fewer active extortion groups, with data leaks rising 50%, ReliaQuest researchers report

item.title: US Data Breaches Hit Record High but Victim Numbers Decline
item.description: Non-profit ITRC says the number of data breaches increased 5% annually to reach a record total in 2025

item.title: Survey of 100+ Energy Systems Reveals Critical OT Cybersecurity Gaps
item.description: A study by OMICRON has revealed widespread cybersecurity gaps in the operational technology (OT) networks of substations, power plants, and control centers worldwide. Drawing on data from more than 100 installations, the analysis highlights recurring technical, organizational, and functional issues that leave critical energy infrastructure vulnerable to cyber threats. The findings are based on
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: 3 Decisions CISOs Need to Make to Prevent Downtime Risk in 2026
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ShinyHunters Claims 14M Panera Bread Records Exposed in Data Breach
item.description: <p>The dataset allegedly includes names, email addresses, postal addresses, phone numbers, and account-related details. </p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-panera-bread-data-breach/">ShinyHunters Claims 14M Panera Bread Records Exposed in Data Breach</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Number of Cybersecurity Pros Surges 194% in Four Years
item.description: Cybersecurity is now the fifth fastest-growing occupation in the UK, says Socura

item.title: SolarWinds Fixes Four Critical Web Help Desk Flaws With Unauthenticated RCE and Auth Bypass
item.description:
SolarWinds has released security updates to address multiple security vulnerabilities impacting SolarWinds Web Help Desk, including four critical vulnerabilities that could result in authentication bypass and remote code execution (RCE). The list of vulnerabilities is as follows -
CVE-2025-40536 (CVSS score: 8.1) - A security control bypass vulnerability that could allow an unauthenticated
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Cybersecurity Teams Embrace AI, Just Not at the Scale Marketing Suggests
item.description: Despite the seemingly widespread adoption of AI for security operations, security leaders primarily use it for “relatively basic use cases,” said a Sumo Logic study

item.title: Google Disrupts IPIDEA — One of the World’s Largest Residential Proxy Networks
item.description: Google on Wednesday announced that it worked together with other partners to disrupt IPIDEA, which it described as one of the largest residential proxy networks in the world. To that end, the company said it took legal action to take down dozens of domains used to control devices and proxy traffic through them. As of writing, IPIDEA's website ("www.ipidea.io") is no longer accessible. It
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Productivity at a Price: The Rising Cost of AI Convenience | UpGuard
item.description: AI tools offer efficiency, but at a cost. UpGuard reveals how PII leaks and new supply chain vulnerabilities are hidden in widely used AI workflows.

item.title: Emerging Risks: Typosquatting in the MCP Ecosystem | UpGuard
item.description: The MCP server ecosystem is susceptible to brand impersonation for both local and remote servers.

item.title: How Can CISOs Respond to Ransomware Getting More Violent?
item.description: Ransomware defense requires focusing on business resilience. This means patching issues promptly, improving user education, and deploying multifactor authentication.
item.dc:creator: James Doggett

item.title: Months After Patch, WinRAR Bug Poised to Hit SMBs Hardest
item.description: Russian and Chinese nation-state attackers are exploiting a months-old WinRAR vulnerability, despite a patch that came out last July.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Fortinet Confirms New Zero-Day Behind Malicious SSO Logins
item.description: To stop the ongoing attacks, the cybersecurity vendor took the drastic step of temporarily disabling FortiCloud single sign-on (SSO) authentication for all devices.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Consumers Reluctant to Shop at Stores That Don't Take Security Seriously
item.description: The retail sector must adapt as consumers become more cybersecurity-conscious. Increased attack transparency is a good place to start.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: WhatsApp Adds One-Tap Security Settings for Added Privacy
item.description: <p>WhatsApp rolled out Strict Account Settings, a lockdown-style mode that blocks unknown attachments, disables link previews, and silences unknown callers.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-whatsapp-strict-account-settings-lockdown-security-mode/">WhatsApp Adds One-Tap Security Settings for Added Privacy</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Kezia Jungco

item.title: Fake Moltbot AI Coding Assistant on VS Code Marketplace Drops Malware
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have flagged a new malicious Microsoft Visual Studio Code (VS Code) extension for Moltbot (formerly Clawdbot) on the official Extension Marketplace that claims to be a free artificial intelligence (AI) coding assistant, but stealthily drops a malicious payload on compromised hosts. The extension, named "ClawdBot Agent - AI Coding Assistant" ("clawdbot.clawdbot-agent")
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Coffee with the Council Podcast: PCI SSC Releases Version 2.0 of the PCI Secure Software Standard
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: China-Backed 'PeckBirdy' Takes Flight for Cross-Platform Attacks
item.description: In two separate campaigns, attackers used the JScript C2 framework to target Chinese gambling websites and Asian government entities with new backdoors.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Russia-Aligned ELECTRUM Tied to December 2025 Cyber Attack on Polish Power Grid
item.description: The "coordinated" cyber attack targeting multiple sites across the Polish power grid has been attributed with medium confidence to a Russian state-sponsored hacking crew known as ELECTRUM. Operational technology (OT) cybersecurity company Dragos, in a new intelligence brief published Tuesday, described the late December 2025 activity as the first major cyber attack targeting distributed energy
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Surging Cyberattacks Boost Latin America to Riskiest Region
item.description: The region is up against tactics like data-leak extortion, credential-stealing campaigns, edge-device exploitation, and attackers leveraging AI.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Two High-Severity n8n Flaws Allow Authenticated Remote Code Execution
item.description:
Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed two new security flaws in the n8n workflow automation platform, including a crucial vulnerability that could result in remote code execution. The weaknesses, discovered by the JFrog Security Research team, are listed below -
CVE-2026-1470 (CVSS score: 9.9) - An eval injection vulnerability that could allow an authenticated user to bypass the Expression
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: From Triage to Threat Hunts: How AI Accelerates SecOps
item.description: If you work in security operations, the concept of the AI SOC agent is likely familiar. Early narratives promised total autonomy. Vendors seized on the idea of the "Autonomous SOC" and suggested a future where algorithms replaced analysts. That future has not arrived. We have not seen mass layoffs or empty security operations centers. We have instead seen the emergence of a practical reality.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Critical vm2 Node.js Flaw Allows Sandbox Escape and Arbitrary Code Execution
item.description: A critical sandbox escape vulnerability has been disclosed in the popular vm2 Node.js library that, if successfully exploited, could allow attackers to run arbitrary code on the underlying operating system. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-22709, carries a CVSS score of 9.8 out of 10.0 on the CVSS scoring system. "In vm2 for version 3.10.0, Promise.prototype.then Promise.prototype.catch
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Mustang Panda Deploys Updated COOLCLIENT Backdoor in Government Cyber Attacks
item.description: Threat actors with ties to China have been observed using an updated version of a backdoor called COOLCLIENT in cyber espionage attacks in 2025 to facilitate comprehensive data theft from infected endpoints. The activity has been attributed to Mustang Panda (aka Earth Preta, Fireant, HoneyMyte, Polaris, and Twill Typhoon) with the intrusions primarily directed against government entities located
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Trump’s Acting Cyber Chief Allegedly Leaked Data to ChatGPT
item.description: <p>Sources say event triggered internal cybersecurity alerts and a DHS–level review into whether federal information had been improperly exposed.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-cisa-cyber-chief-chatgpt/">Trump&#8217;s Acting Cyber Chief Allegedly Leaked Data to ChatGPT</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Password Reuse in Disguise: An Often-Missed Risky Workaround
item.description: When security teams discuss credential-related risk, the focus typically falls on threats such as phishing, malware, or ransomware. These attack methods continue to evolve and rightly command attention. However, one of the most persistent and underestimated risks to organizational security remains far more ordinary. Near-identical password reuse continues to slip past security controls, often
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Love? Actually: Fake dating app used as lure in targeted spyware campaign in Pakistan
item.description: ESET researchers discover an Android spyware campaign targeting users in Pakistan via romance scam tactics, revealing links to a broader spy operation

item.title: Google Warns of Active Exploitation of WinRAR Vulnerability CVE-2025-8088
item.description: Google on Tuesday revealed that multiple threat actors, including nation-state adversaries and financially motivated groups, are exploiting a now-patched critical security flaw in RARLAB WinRAR to establish initial access and deploy a diverse array of payloads. "Discovered and patched in July 2025, government-backed threat actors linked to Russia and China as well as financially motivated
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Fake Python Spellchecker Packages on PyPI Delivered Hidden Remote Access Trojan
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered two malicious packages in the Python Package Index (PyPI) repository that masquerade as spellcheckers but contain functionality to deliver a remote access trojan (RAT). The packages, named spellcheckerpy and spellcheckpy, are no longer available on PyPI, but not before they were collectively downloaded a little over 1,000 times. "Hidden inside the Basque
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Android Phones Get AI-Powered Anti-Theft Features
item.description: <p>Enhanced lockouts and stronger remote locking aim to make stolen devices far harder—and less profitable—for criminals.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-android-anti-theft-features/">Android Phones Get AI-Powered Anti-Theft Features</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Fortinet Patches CVE-2026-24858 After Active FortiOS SSO Exploitation Detected
item.description: Fortinet has begun releasing security updates to address a critical flaw impacting FortiOS that has come under active exploitation in the wild. The vulnerability, assigned the CVE identifier CVE-2026-24858 (CVSS score: 9.4), has been described as an authentication bypass related to FortiOS single sign-on (SSO). The flaw also affects FortiManager and FortiAnalyzer. The company said it's
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI &amp; the Death of Accuracy: What It Means for Zero-Trust
item.description: AI &quot;model collapse,&quot; where LLMs over time train on more and more AI-generated data and become degraded as a result, can introduce inaccuracies, promulgate malicious activity, and impact PII protections.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Microsoft Issues Emergency Patch for Active Office Zero-Day
item.description: <p>Microsoft released an emergency Office patch to fix an actively exploited zero-day flaw that lets attackers bypass security via malicious files.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-microsoft-office-zero-day-emergency-patch-january-2026/">Microsoft Issues Emergency Patch for Active Office Zero-Day</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: Vibe-Coded 'Sicarii' Ransomware Can't Be Decrypted
item.description: A new ransomware strain that entered the scene last year has poorly designed code and uses Hebrew language that might be a false flag.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Critical Telnet Server Flaw Exposes Forgotten Attack Surface
item.description: While telnet is considered obsolete, the network protocol is still used by hundreds of thousands of legacy systems and IoT devices for remote access.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Microsoft Rushes Emergency Patch for Office Zero-Day
item.description: To exploit the vulnerability, an attacker would need either system access or be able to convince a user to open a malicious Office file.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Apple Issues Urgent Software Fix Affecting Over 2 Billion iPhones
item.description: <p>Apple released urgent iOS updates, including iOS 12.5.8 for older iPhones, after emergency-call issues in Australia and a 2027 certificate deadline.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-apple-urgent-iphone-software-update-january-2026/">Apple Issues Urgent Software Fix Affecting Over 2 Billion iPhones</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Aminu Abdullahi

item.title: 'Stanley' Toolkit Turns Chrome Into Undetectable Phishing Vector
item.description: The malware-as-a-service kit enables malicious extensions to overlay pages on real websites without changing the visible URL, signaling a fresh challenge for enterprise security.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: WhatsApp Rolls Out Lockdown-Style Security Mode to Protect Targeted Users From Spyware
item.description: Meta on Tuesday announced it's adding Strict Account Settings on WhatsApp to secure certain users against advanced cyber attacks because of who they are and what they do. The feature, similar to Lockdown Mode in Apple iOS and Advanced Protection in Android, aims to protect individuals, such as journalists or public-facing figures, from sophisticated spyware by trading some functionality for
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Experts Detect Pakistan-Linked Cyber Campaigns Aimed at Indian Government Entities
item.description: Indian government entities have been targeted in two campaigns undertaken by a threat actor that operates in Pakistan using previously undocumented tradecraft. The campaigns have been codenamed Gopher Strike and Sheet Attack by Zscaler ThreatLabz, which identified them in September 2025. "While these campaigns share some similarities with the Pakistan-linked Advanced Persistent Threat (APT)
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: WorldLeaks Extortion Group Claims It Stole 1.4TB of Nike Data
item.description: The sportswear brand is investigating an alleged breach of its network that exposed some 188,347 files of highly sensitive corporate data.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: ClickFix Attacks Expand Using Fake CAPTCHAs, Microsoft Scripts, and Trusted Web Services
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new campaign that combines ClickFix-style fake CAPTCHAs with a signed Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) script to distribute an information stealer called Amatera. "Instead of launching PowerShell directly, the attacker uses this script to control how execution begins and to avoid more common, easily recognized execution paths,"
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Hand CVE Over to the Private Sector
item.description: How MITRE has mismanaged the world's vulnerability database for decades and wasted millions along the way.
item.dc:creator: Brian Martin

item.title: The Constitutionality of Geofence Warrants
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Celebrating Data Privacy Week with NIST’s Privacy Engineering Program
item.description: Grab your party hats – it’s Data Privacy Week! Data Privacy Week is a global initiative led by the National Cybersecurity Alliance to spread awareness about online privacy and empower individuals and businesses to respect privacy, safeguard data, and enable trust. In celebration of this week, the NIST Privacy Engineering Program is reflecting on recent work and looking ahead to what’s coming in the new year. Throughout 2026, we plan to continue collaborating with our privacy stakeholder community to develop and advance privacy risk management guidelines to help organizations of all sizes
item.dc:creator: Ellen Nadeau, Meghan Anderson, Nakia Grayson, Diane Wertime

item.title: CTEM in Practice: Prioritization, Validation, and Outcomes That Matter
item.description: Cybersecurity teams increasingly want to move beyond looking at threats and vulnerabilities in isolation. It’s not only about what could go wrong (vulnerabilities) or who might attack (threats), but where they intersect in your actual environment to create real, exploitable exposure. Which exposures truly matter? Can attackers exploit them? Are our defenses effective? Continuous Threat Exposure
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Office Zero-Day (CVE-2026-21509) - Emergency Patch Issued for Active Exploitation
item.description: Microsoft on Monday issued out-of-band security patches for a high-severity Microsoft Office zero-day vulnerability exploited in attacks. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-21509, carries a CVSS score of 7.8 out of 10.0. It has been described as a security feature bypass in Microsoft Office. "Reliance on untrusted inputs in a security decision in Microsoft Office allows an unauthorized
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Critical Grist-Core Vulnerability Allows RCE Attacks via Spreadsheet Formulas
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Drowning in spam or scam emails? Here’s probably why
item.description: Has your inbox recently been deluged with unwanted and even outright malicious messages? Here are 10 possible reasons – and how to stem the tide.

item.title: China-Linked Hackers Have Used the PeckBirdy JavaScript C2 Framework Since 2023
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a JScript-based command-and-control (C2) framework called PeckBirdy that has been put to use by China-aligned APT actors since 2023 to target multiple environments. The flexible framework has been put to use against Chinese gambling industries and malicious activities targeting Asian government entities and private organizations, according to Trend Micro
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Beauty in Destruction: Exploring Malware's Impact Through Art
item.description: Artistic initiatives turn cybersecurity into immersive exhibits at the Museum of Malware Art, transforming digital threats into thought-provoking experiences.
item.dc:creator: Andrada Fiscutean

item.title: Sandworm Blamed for Wiper Attack on Polish Power Grid
item.description: Researchers attributed the failed attempt to the infamous Russian APT Sandworm, which is notorious for wiper attacks on critical infrastructure organizations.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Indian Users Targeted in Tax Phishing Campaign Delivering Blackmoon Malware
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered an ongoing campaign that's targeting Indian users with a multi-stage backdoor as part of a suspected cyber espionage campaign. The activity, per the eSentire Threat Response Unit (TRU), involves using phishing emails impersonating the Income Tax Department of India to trick victims into downloading a malicious archive, ultimately granting the threat
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Shared BitLocker Keys With FBI, Raising Privacy Fears
item.description: <p>Microsoft confirmed it can hand over BitLocker recovery keys stored in the cloud under warrant, reviving debate over who controls encrypted data.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-microsoft-bitlocker-keys-fbi-privacy/">Microsoft Shared BitLocker Keys With FBI, Raising Privacy Fears</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Aminu Abdullahi

item.title: DPRK's Konni Targets Blockchain Developers With AI-Generated Backdoor
item.description: The North Korean threat group is using a new PowerShell backdoor to compromise development environments and target cryptocurrency holdings, according to researchers.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Malicious VS Code AI Extensions with 1.5 Million Installs Steal Developer Source Code
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered two malicious Microsoft Visual Studio Code (VS Code) extensions that are advertised as artificial intelligence (AI)-powered coding assistants, but also harbor covert functionality to siphon developer data to China-based servers. The extensions, which have 1.5 million combined installs and are still available for download from the official Visual Studio
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Ireland Proposes Giving Police New Digital Surveillance Powers
item.description: <p>This is <a href="https://www.theregister.com/2026/01/21/ireland_wants_to_give_police/">coming</a>:</p> <blockquote><p>The Irish government is planning to bolster its police&#8217;s ability to intercept communications, including encrypted messages, and provide a legal basis for spyware use.</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Firewall Flaws, AI-Built Malware, Browser Traps, Critical CVEs & More
item.description: Security failures rarely arrive loudly. They slip in through trusted tools, half-fixed problems, and habits people stop questioning. This week’s recap shows that pattern clearly. Attackers are moving faster than defenses, mixing old tricks with new paths. “Patched” no longer means safe, and every day, software keeps becoming the entry point. What follows is a set of small but telling signals.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Winning Against AI-Based Attacks Requires a Combined Defensive Approach
item.description: If there’s a constant in cybersecurity, it’s that adversaries are always innovating. The rise of offensive AI is transforming attack strategies and making them harder to detect. Google’s Threat Intelligence Group, recently reported on adversaries using Large Language Models (LLMs) to both conceal code and generate malicious scripts on the fly, letting malware shape-shift in real-time to evade
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Gmail Spam Filter Breakdown Affects 1.8B Users
item.description: <p>The disruption began Saturday (5am Pacific time, Jan .24) affecting approximately 1.8 billion Gmail users worldwide with widespread email misclassification.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-gmail-spam-filter-breaks/">Gmail Spam Filter Breakdown Affects 1.8B Users</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Konni Hackers Deploy AI-Generated PowerShell Backdoor Against Blockchain Developers
item.description: The North Korean threat actor known as Konni has been observed using PowerShell malware generated using artificial intelligence (AI) tools to target developers and engineering teams in the blockchain sector. The phishing campaign has targeted Japan, Australia, and India, highlighting the adversary's expansion of the targeting scope beyond South Korea, Russia, Ukraine, and European nations, Check
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Multi-Stage Phishing Campaign Targets Russia with Amnesia RAT and Ransomware
item.description: A new multi-stage phishing campaign has been observed targeting users in Russia with ransomware and a remote access trojan called Amnesia RAT. "The attack begins with social engineering lures delivered via business-themed documents crafted to appear routine and benign," Fortinet FortiGuard Labs researcher Cara Lin said in a technical breakdown published this week. "These documents and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
